title: DKW SS 350
text:
The DKW SS 350 was a <a href="Motorcycle%20racing">racing</a> <a href="motorcycle">motorcycle</a>. 1935 saw the introduction of <a href="Dampf-Kraft-Wagen">Dampf-Kraft-Wagen</a>'s first "over the counter" racer with the announcement of the SS250 at that year's <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a> Show. The model was quickly followed by a 350 cc version, the SS350, which drew on the works team's experience. 
Features.
In the (very limited) production application the <a href="water%20cooling">water-cooled</a> engine retained the vertical cylinder but placed the crank driven <a href="supercharger">supercharger</a> piston and its cylinder under the <a href="crankcase">crankcase</a>s. The <a href="Radiator%20%28engine%20cooling%29">radiator</a> was mounted between the twin downtubes of the plunger suspended double cradle frame and drive was taken to the four speed <a href="gearbox">gearbox</a> via a <a href="Roller%20chain">chain</a> primary drive and dry multidisc <a href="clutch">clutch</a>. Girder <a href="Motorcycle%20fork">forks</a> equipped the front end and were fitted with a full width <a href="Wheel%20hub%20assembly">hub</a> as was the rear wheel.
Engine.
In its 1939, 350 cc form, the SS engine had a <a href="Bore%20%28engine%29">bore</a> of 39.5 mm for each of the two <a href="piston">piston</a>s and a <a href="Stroke%20%28engine%29">stroke</a> of 68.5 mm, which with the aid of the supercharger resulted in a claimed power output of . This compared very favourably with its rivals although the works 350US was reputedly producing
